title: Workshops
text:
These are publicly described, with access to sign up options, at https://csc.ok.ubc.ca/workshops/


All workshops are series based, beginning at the introductory level for those with absolutely no experience, and building up to more advanced concepts.
Individual workshops are scheduled for roughly 1 hour, with 30 minutes of instructor led content, 15 minutes for Q&A related to the content, and 15 minutes for follow up if needed.
Each workshop has its own webpage with the full content of the session, with the intention of having resources for people to revisit after a session, as well as to self-instruct.
Workshop content is meant to be iterative and updated; you are encouraged to make edits and suggestions on both content and delivery approach.

title: Workshops
text:

title: Workshops
text:
Workshop Space
Workshops are hosted out of LIB 111. The CSC Coordinator will provide an introduction to the room.
LIB 111 supports hybrid delivery.

title: Workshops
text:
Workshop Content
All workshops are written in notebook format (generally RMarkdown), centralized in GitHub, and published through GitHub pages.
If you need to familiarize yourself with RMarkdown, you can check out the Get Started content, and refer to the R Markdown: The Definitive Guide for more thorough documentation.
To build, update, etc. workshop content, you will need to request access to the CSC’s organization on GitHub https://github.com/csc-ubc-okanagan.

title: Workshops
text:
Workshop Delivery
As most, if not all, workshops developed require some live coding, a common approach used by consultants is to do a split screen presentation, with the GitHub pages content on one side and an IDE, or similar working space, on the other.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
text: There are some common scenarios that may occur during your consultation sessions. Below are suggestions on how to handle them effectively:

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
text: There are some common scenarios that may occur during your consultation sessions. Below are suggestions on how to handle them effectively:

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
text:
Individual arrives with no data:
This should be more common than it is. We encourage students to consult at a minimum at three stages during their project: a) prior to data collection; b) post data collection; c) during analysis.
Research Question and Hypotheses
At this stage, it is critical to emphasize the need for a robust, clearly articulated research question and robust, clearly articulated hypotheses. If these cannot be clearly articulated by the student, provide examples, articulate the relevance to statistical analysis, and encourage them to cement these with their supervisor.
Data Collection Plan
Discuss their data collection plan and help to address if it appears to violate standard assumptions. For example,

Is it a random sample?
Is there pseudo replication?
What sample size is sufficient?
Is there a risk of missing data or nonresponse bias?
Directing to Resources

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives with limited ability to describe their data and research questions:
text:
Individual arrives with limited ability to describe their data and research questions:
We want to ensure the student understands how their data relate to their research question and can comfortably describe their data.


Can the student clearly articulate their research question? 1.1 Yes. Proceed to 2. 1.2 No.Communicate the need to define the research question for the validity of statistical analyses. Note the limitations in post hoc articulation of the research question, but proceed.


Can the student clearly articulate their hypothesis? 2.1 Yes. Proceed to 3. 2.2 No.Communicate the need to define a null and alternative. Assist in this. Note limitations in post hoc articulation of the hypothesis, but proceed if they wish to.


Can the student describe their data, including:

How it was collected
The type of data
The measure of the data
The independent and dependent variables. 3.1 No.Walk them through the process of describing their data. Consider helping them create a data dictionary containing this information. Emphasize that a test cannot be selected until the data are understood. 3.2 Yes. Proceed to 4.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives with a dataset asking for support in conducting a particular statistical test of the data:
text:
Individual arrives with a dataset asking for support in conducting a particular statistical test of the data:
We want to ensure that the chosen test is appropriate for the data:


What are the assumptions of the test?


Have these been tested for?

5.1 Yes. Proceed to 3.
5.2 No. How do we test these assumptions? Conduct the tests.

Are any of the assumptions violated?

6.1 No. Is the dataset large enough for the test results to be meaningful?
6.1.1 No. Depending on the project, this may be all that the student has to work with. The limitations should be communicated and a decision made on how to proceed.
6.2 Yes. Is there an alternative test they could use that would be suitable?
6.2.1 Yes. Introduce the alternative.
6.2.2 No, or they wish to use the original test anyway. The limitations should be communicated, the test and its interpretation can be demonstrated anyway.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives with a dataset asking for guidance in selecting a statistical test to analyze the data:
text:
Individual arrives with a dataset asking for guidance in selecting a statistical test to analyze the data:
We want to ensure the student understands how their data relate to specific tests, how then to implement these tests and finally, interpret the results:

Provide the student with options as appropriate, providing guidance if they request it. Demonstrate how to test for assumptions in the test(s), how to implement the test(s), and how to interpret the results.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives with no background in coding or statistical analysis:
text:
Individual arrives with no background in coding or statistical analysis:
You may encounter clients who have no experience with coding in R or Python and limited or no understanding of statistical analysis:

Since our service focuses on using R and Python, it is important to suggest that these clients begin learning the basics of these tools. Encourage them to attend CSC workshops offered throughout the semester, such as Working with R in the first semester and Statistical Fundamentals + Modelling in the second semester. Also, many online resources are available and should be recommended during workshop sessions. Relevant blog posts on the CSC website should be introduced and presented to clients as helpful learning tools.
Depending on the nature of their questions, whether they are about visualization or analysis, you can offer general guidance, such as appropriate types of visualizations or potential statistical tests based on their research questions. However, providing detailed and tailored advice typically requires some foundational statistical knowledge, which the client may not yet have in the first session. In such cases, encourage them to return for follow-up sessions, where more precise and specific guidance can be offered once they have a stronger understanding.
You should not write entire scripts for clients, as this is outside the scope of our data consultation services. If clients request a full script, please note that this is not within the scope of our services, but you would be happy to help them troubleshoot or use the proper approach to their own written code.
You may encounter clients who are working with other statistical tools such as SPSS or STATA/MP and are seeking guidance on their analysis. While you can offer general advice on data analysis approaches, you may not be able to provide hands-on support with these specific software programs, depending on your own expertise and experience. It is recommended to communicate and clarify this with the client before the session so they have a clear understanding of what kind of support they can expect.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives experiencing difficulties with their coding:
text:
Individual arrives experiencing difficulties with their coding:
Sometimes, you may have clients who are moderately proficient in coding but are facing issues in their scripts:

This is often seen in clients who are trying to model their data or who have used AI-generated codes without fully understanding their purpose. In such cases, it is recommended that you first gain a full understanding of their dataset and research question. The imported data should be explored to ensure there are no issues with the data itself. More tailored help can be provided once you understand the specific error they are encountering.
You may quickly develop an idea of what kind of code and analysis would be suitable after seeing their data and research questions. If it becomes clear that the client is using uncommon packages or methods, it is a good idea to introduce them to more standard or widely accepted approaches for analysis.
Keep in mind that you are not expected to be familiar with every potential error in R or Python. Sometimes, identifying the root cause takes time. In such situations, you can work with a sample dataset provided by the client on your own machine after the session and follow up with them once you have resolved or identified the issue.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives working with less common types of data:
text:
Individual arrives working with less common types of data:
You may encounter clients who are working with unusual or less common types of data as part of their thesis or course project:

In such cases, it may not be possible to provide precise guidance during the session due to the complexity or uncommon structure of their data. These situations might require you to explore the problem further on your own and follow up with the client afterward.
For example, a client might be working with data where the outcome variable is continuous, not normally distributed, and includes true zeros and positive values (not necessarily counts). This restricts the use of many commonly applied distributions in standard modeling approaches. In such scenarios, the Tweedie distribution is often recommended, as it can accommodate both zero values and positive continuous outcomes in the same model.

title: Scenarios in Data Consultations
section: Individual arrives seeking support for non-data-related questions:
text:
Individual arrives seeking support for non-data-related questions:

Some clients may seek our services for help with their research proposals or presentations, especially when discussing the statistical analysis section of their methodology. In some cases, you might notice that their writing needs significant improvement. When this happens, it is helpful to recommend that they also take advantage of other services offered by CSC, such as writing consultations. For guidance, see the section on referrals.

title: UBCO CSC Graduate Data Services
text:
The CSC’s graduate data service is designed to support graduate and undergraduate research activities and is comprised of three elements:

workshops
bookable, one-on-one consultations
a blog

These three elements are intended to compliment each other. Workshops provide basic skill development in tools (R and / or Python) and core concepts (conceptual understandings of core statistical concepts); these skillsets enable students to come to a consultation that is designed to help them problem solve an issue in preparing, understanding, evaluating, and interpreting their data, their code, and their analyses; the blog post, as much as possible, offers a resource for students to return to in between consultations.
In addition to these core elements, referrals to expertise elsewhere within the CSC are encouraged.

title: UBCO CSC Graduate Data Services
text:
The CSC’s graduate data service is designed to support graduate and undergraduate research activities and is comprised of three elements:

workshops
bookable, one-on-one consultations
a blog

These three elements are intended to compliment each other. Workshops provide basic skill development in tools (R and / or Python) and core concepts (conceptual understandings of core statistical concepts); these skillsets enable students to come to a consultation that is designed to help them problem solve an issue in preparing, understanding, evaluating, and interpreting their data, their code, and their analyses; the blog post, as much as possible, offers a resource for students to return to in between consultations.
In addition to these core elements, referrals to expertise elsewhere within the CSC are encouraged.

title: UBCO CSC Graduate Data Services
text:
User Facing Experience
The user facing introduction to these three services can be found at https://csc-ubc-okanagan.github.io/.

title: Consultations
text:
This is outlined more concisely for students at https://csc.ok.ubc.ca/consultations/research-data-consultation/. This is also where students can access the booking form.


The data consultation service is premised on enhancing the graduate and undergraduate research learning experience at UBCO, providing students with an opporutnity to build new skill sets that are transferable to future problems. As such, the intent of the service is not to solve the problem for the student, but to navigate them through the problem solving process, helping them to identify a solution that they understand, can implement, and is appropriate for their discipline, their data, and their research question.
The service is delivered with the underlying philosophy of engaging students in transparent and reproducible methods, hence the focus on open source and scripted tools for analysis. However, this should be extended to include principles such as maintianing a read only version of the raw data, not overwriting data, and maintaining documentation in the form of readmes and data dictionaries. These, and other good research practices related to data management should be encouraged during consultations.
However, this can be challenging for several reasons. Students may:

have limited skillsets in the use of R or Python
come with immediate deadlines they need to meet
have an expectation that someone else will do the work for them
be less interested in understanding the problem than simply having a solution
lack PI or other faculty support in adhering to best practices in data managmenet and statistical methods
and more…

These are factors that need to be mediated and benefit from seeking clarification from the student. Ultimately, it is not up to a consultant to tell a student how their work should be done, nor is it their responsibility to navigate the relationship between a student and their supervisor or other project lead. However, it is critical to be clear on the scope of services available. If at any stage there is concern about conflict in managing these challenges, the consultant should bring the issue directly to their supervisor to support a resolution.



Objectives of the Service

Provide guidance on the writing of code to clean, organize, and otherwise prepare data for analysis.
Provide guidance on interpreting errors and identifying solutions to overcome these.
Provide guidance on the selection, application, and interpretation of statistical models used in analysis.

Outcomes of the Service

Users will be able to write clearer, more reliable code
Users will be able to interpret the error messages they receive and resolve them.
Users will gain insights into the appropriate selection, application, and interpretation of statistical methods and models

Example Activities Supporting these Outcomes and Objectives

Assist in drafting code to address an error
Provide sample code to move a dataset through the data analysis pipeline (cleaning, organizing, imputing, etc) (this may be substantive)
Describe the applicability and interpretation of a statistical model
Advise on the selection of a statistical model, ideally before data collection
Draft code to demonstrate the implementation a specific model (this may be substantive)
As possible, draft all code on a random sample of the supplied data




Out of Scope

Writing the full analysis pipeline
Class assignment support

title: Consultations
text:

title: Consultations
section: What is Communicated to Booking Students
text:
What is Communicated to Booking Students
When booking a consultation, students are asked to provide certain key pieces of information to assist you in helping them and to sign off on a number of things that relate to academic and scholarly integrity.
This booking form is managed in LibCal, and once your account is set up, can be accessed by navigating to Appointments > Booking Forms. You should familiarize yourself with this form. If you find that the form is not sufficiently capturing what is needed to facilitate your consultations, you are encouraged to suggest updates.
Students are also provided with two additional links, one for What to Expect During Your Research Data Consultation, and for What Should I Bring to a Consultation?. You should familiarize yourself with these two documents. They can also be referenced to help set expectations for a consultation. As above, you are encouraged to suggest edits and updates.

title: Consultations
text:
Consultation Space
Consultations may be provided in person or over Zoom. If you do not yet have a Zoom account through UBC, the CSC Coordinator or your supervisor can help set this up.
For in person consultations, we have both LIB 223 and LIB 225 available. You should have Salto access to these two rooms as well as access to the calendars. If you have neither of these, the CSC Coordinator or your supervisor can help set this up.

title: Consultations
text:
Consultations & Academic / Scholarly Integrity
It is important to be cognizant of when help begins to infringe on academic and scholarly integrity. This is all the more difficult as different supervisors, collaborators, and disciplines have differing expectations on the scope of support that is legitimate. In some cases, it may be appropriate to write code for an analysis, so long as attribution is provided. In other cases, it may be unacceptable for the student to use code drafted by someone else. The former may be the case if the purpose of the required understanding is the conceptual approach and output; the latter if the required understanding includes a level of mastery of the language.
It is importnat to communicate during a consultation that the student should engage with their collaborators and supervisor on the level of support that they are getting; an effective way of doing this is to ask them to solicit feedback on a proposed solution or path forward followed by booking another consultation when things are agreed upon by the research team (possibly just the student and their supervisor).
Because writing and trouble shooting code can be a very hands on activity, we have the following guide to help limit the level of ‘authoring’ the data consultant engages in and how much of the original data any authoring happens on:



Activity
Location




trouble shoot code
on their machine, full data set


write code
on their machine, using a sample


troubleshoot a model
on their machine, full data set


write / customize a model
on their machine, using a sample


interpret findings
on their machine, full data set




Handling Substantive Contributions
In spite of being aware and taking precautions, you may well end up in a situation feeling like you’re making ‘substantive’ contributions to the student’s project. In such cases you should always make your supervisor aware of the situation.
Examples of how these situations might be navigated include:

When ‘substantive’ contributions are being made to overcome a lack of understanding on the user’s part (this is in contrast to a ‘substantive’ contribution whose primary purpose is demonstration). In these cases, the student should be referred to their supervisor for guidance and may be referred to other self-guided resources or workshops.
When ‘substantive’ makes you think your contributions warrant acknowledgement. In these cases, the student should be made aware of this fact.
When ‘substantive’ makes you think your contributions warrant co-authorship. You should be thinking about this before we get to this stage. If acknowledgment is veering toward co-authorship, this should be clarified with the student and the conversation should include other co-authors and consent from the PI. Your manager / supervisor should also be alerted. If work does veer in this direction, it as the discretion of the consultant to pursue this collaboration outside of their data consultant role.

title: Consultations
text:
Booking Procedures

Consultation Bookings
We use LibCal for consultation booking. The CSC coordinator will help to get you set with a profile and review with you how LibCal works.

title: Consultations
text:
Preparing for the consultation
When booking a consultation, students will be asked if they will be bringing code and / or data to the consultation. If they answer yes, you are to create a folder for them, titled with their name, and invite them to it, asking them to deposit any materials at least 24 hours in advance of the consultation.
You will need to request access yourself to the data-deposit/ directory, if you don’t already have access. You can do so by clicking on this link.
Consultations are booked in one hour slots. Time management is very important, and it’s important to reasonably limit the scope of what can be covered in a single consultation, encouraging students to book follow up appointments. It is also advisable, when doing time management with a consultation, to aim for 45 minutes, giving yourseld a 15 minute buffer.
This being said, each one hour consultation could easily take 2 hours of your time, especially if this is the first time the student is booking. It is expected that you will take some time to review any deposited code, data, and associated documentation in advance of the consultation. It is also expected that you will take some time responding post consultation via email to the student, summarizing what was covered in the session and what you’ve agreed on for next steps.
It is also expected that you may need to do spend some time investigating or researching novel concepts that arise during a consultation to effectively support a student. If you find yourself requiring more than an hour in such follow up research, bring this to the attention of your supervisor for discussion on how best to approach balancing what might become competing interests on having time for consultations, time for preparation and follow up, and time for skills and knowledge development.

title: Referrals
text:
The data consultant service is part of a much larger research support network at UBCO, centralized through the CSC.
As appropriate, when students have questions or require additional support, they should be referred to the relevant expertise, which may include questions or issues related to ethics, software support, compute infrastructure, thesis formatting, copyright, publishing agreements, writing support, finding data, conducting literature reviews, etc.
You should familiarize yourself with the scope of supports available, as listed below, and redirect as necessary and appropriate. If in doubt, refer to the CSC Coordinator or your supervisor.

title: Referrals
text:
The data consultant service is part of a much larger research support network at UBCO, centralized through the CSC.
As appropriate, when students have questions or require additional support, they should be referred to the relevant expertise, which may include questions or issues related to ethics, software support, compute infrastructure, thesis formatting, copyright, publishing agreements, writing support, finding data, conducting literature reviews, etc.
You should familiarize yourself with the scope of supports available, as listed below, and redirect as necessary and appropriate. If in doubt, refer to the CSC Coordinator or your supervisor.

title: Referrals
text:
Referrals within the CSC
The CSC is designed to bring together all research supports at UBC Okanagan under a common umbrella to facilitate, for researchers, navigating the supports and expertise available to them. Below, we try to provide context for when referrals should be made, both by office or service as well as by where in the research life cycle a user is at.
Referrals are encouraged and should be made by way of a cc’d email to csc.ok@ubc.ca (i.e. email the CSC with the user cc’d requesting a referral with a brief summary of the context).

title: Referrals
text:
CSC Partners & Services

ORS
The Office of Research Services at UBC Okanagan supports all aspects of pre-study implementation, including grant funding and ethics.
Users looking for support with funding, ethics, and related compliance, should be referred to ORS via their supervisor or PI, as appropriate.
Learn more about UBCO’s ORS scope of services here, and meat their team here.


Research Computing
Research Computing provides direct support to UBC Okanagan researchers, including ongoing research IT support, hardware & software setup, quotes, consultations, installation, troubleshooting and configuration.
Users looking for support with institutionally provisioned hardware or software, or asking questions about storage, server space, high performance computing and questions of this nature, should be referred to Research Computing.
Learn more about their services here.


Library
The Library supports multiple research related activities. It is the primary point of contact for:

literature and data discovery
secondary research (literature reviews, meta-analyses)
copyright
research data management
scholarly communication (metrics, publisher agreements, etc)

The library runs both a functional and subject based model: each faculty or department has a subject librarian; primary functional roles (copyright, data, collections, etc.) are assigned to individual librarians.
Users looking to acquire literature or data, get methodolgical support for secondary research, resolve a copyright or licencing concern, organize or deposit research data, or navigate issues related to scholarly communication, should be redirected to their subject or relevant functional librarian.
Find a list of librarians by subject here.


Writing Consultations
The CSC offers graduate and faculty writing and presentation support; this is available for any scholarly output including conferences, publications etc.
Users looking for support in preparing presentations, drafting articles, etc. should be referred to these writing supports.
Learn more about the CSC’s writing supports here.


Data Consultations
The CSC offers graduate and faculty data and statistics support. This includes connecting data and statistics to study design, data wrangling (cleaning, formatting, etc), and selection and interpretation of statistical tests.
Learn more about the CSC’s data supports here.


College of Graduate Studies
Graduate users who have questions or concerns relating to University operations or conduct (awards, conflict, graudation, etc) should be referred to CoGS.
Learn more about CoGS here.


University Industry Liaison Office
Users engaged in research with any partner external to UBC that may involve in exchange of data, information, etc should be referred to the ULIO via their supervisor or PI, as appropriate.
Learn more about UILO services at UBC Okanagan here.

title: Blog Posts
text:
Blog posts should help address common, repeat questions from students that are easily generalizeable. As much as possible, they should be concise and focused on a very specific task.
You are encouraged to update old posts and draft new content.

title: Blog Posts
text:
Blog posts should help address common, repeat questions from students that are easily generalizeable. As much as possible, they should be concise and focused on a very specific task.
You are encouraged to update old posts and draft new content.

title: Blog Posts
text:
Creating Posts
We use Blogdown to write and release content hosted on GitHub pages. The CSC Data Blog repository, along with instructions for drafting, building, and pushing content can be found at https://github.com/csc-ubc-okanagan/csc-data-blog.
You are encouraged to actively contribute to the site’s documentation if you identify gaps, to address updates, errors, etc.
The blog can be accessed at https://csc-ubc-okanagan.github.io/csc-data-blog/.
